awd_titl_txt: CRII: CIF: Generalizations for Matrix and Tensor Estimation
awd_abstract_narration:
Matrix and tensor estimation are core building blocks in data science and machine learning for dealing with missing data. They have been used widely across many domains, including social computing, computer vision, and computational biology. This project seeks to advance these techniques to handle model variations that are seen in real world datasets; in particular, data collection is rarely uniform, and there is often a mix of interaction data and covariate or feature information. As an example, a biological dataset might contain known properties of individual genes, in addition to information about how genes interact. The interaction data is collected from real experiments and thus may be highly non-uniformly distributed. The techniques developed from this project could enable more efficient predictions over this dataset given less experimental data.

The technical goals of this project involve generalizing matrix and tensor estimation theory and algorithms beyond uniform sampling models, and designing optimally efficient algorithms that incorporate side information together with matrix interaction data. The approach proposed focuses on similarity based collaborative filtering algorithms. For each of these model variations, the researchers plan to characterize information theoretic thresholds and minimax optimal estimation error rates, design and analyze computationally and statistically efficient algorithms, and provide confidence sets to quantify uncertainty of estimates. These results will greatly increase the flexibility of matrix and tensor estimation methods to be used for sequential decision making and high dimensional scientific data analyses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
The high level aim of this project was to advance the state of the art in matrix and tensor estimation to account for non-uniform sampling models, and to effectively utilize available side information beyond the matrix and tensor data. As matrix and tensor estimation is a core building block for data science and machine learning, there is a need for robust theory and practical guidelines for the usage of matrix and tensor estimation in practical scenarios where sampling models are typically non-uniform and side information is readily available. Below are key contributions that resulted from work done on this grant:

 1. New algorithms and robust analysis for matrix and tensor estimation, allowing for arbitrary bounded perturbation and approximately low rank models.

2. New result showing that with a minimal amount of weak side information, tensor estimation can be reduced to matrix estimation, reducing the sample complexity significantly to match the statistical lower bound. This result contrasts the conjectured computational statistical gap in tensor estimation without side information.

3. New analysis that characterizes minimax optimal rates of estimation for the setting of nonparametric matrix estimation with one-sided covariates. When there is sufficiently rich information associated to the covariates, then simple regression will achieve optimal rates. Otherwise, collaborative filtering approaches for matrix estimation that share data across similar units will significantly improve the estimates to achieve optimal rates.

4. Preliminary results for entry specific guarantees for matrix estimation under highly non-uniform sampling models. We provide a simple algorithm that achieves entry-specific minimax optimal bounds in limited settings.

5. The work on matrix estimation has also resulted in novel algorithms and analyses for online decision making algorithms that utilize matrix estimation subroutines. In particular we have developed algorithms that utilize matrix estimation to exploit low rank structure for reinforcement learning for more efficient learning.

The work done on this project has been widely disseminated in various IEEE, ACM, and INFORMS venues, and have resulted in a 2023 ACM SIGMETRICS Best Student Paper Award. The PI has also spoke on this work at diversity and outreach initiatives at Cornell to women in Computer Science and Engineering. A student supported on this grant has obtained internships in industry and a machine learning engineer position post-graduation. The PI has organized and participated in faculty research panels yearly for underrepresented minorities and first-generation students as part of Cornell's Diversity Programs in Engineering.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2023
Modified by: Christina L Yu
